text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Thursday.

- A U.S. information agency (USIA) poll shows Tudjman's popularity unscathed by recent popular protests in Zagreb. Some 81 percent of those polled said the president was "extremely popular", and 77 percent thought he was "doing a good job".
- The government and trade unions of public sector, culture workers and of air traffic controllers agreed a 5.0 percent wage increase next year.
- Euthanasia, until now treated as murder under the Croatian law, is to be regulated by a separate criminal act. Perpetrators will get milder prison sentences ranging from six months to five years.
- October workforce revised up to 1.4 million by including army, police and farmers, but still down by 0.6 percent from the previous month.
- Cable maker Elka expects an income of 452 million kuna in 1996, 15 million kuna profit -- about the same as last year.
- In 1996, some 0.57 percent of pork meat found to have been infected by 'Trichinelosa', an animal disease that can affect humans. This was up from 0.24 percent detected in 1995.
- Croatia opted for Airbus planes because of low costs of their maintenance, says Jean-Pierre Vernon, the company's sales director for Central and Eastern Europe.

- Foreign Ministry says General Tihomir Blaskic, indicted by the U.N. war crimes tribunal last November, had actually been awarded a medal for his participation in Croatian 1995 military actions before the ICTY pressed charges against him.
- Interest rates on kuna savings paid by Croatian banks are much higher than on foreign currency deposits.

- EBRD rates the kuna as the second most stable currency in Europe, behind the Dutch guilder. Croatia also tops the list of countries in transition according to economic growth. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
